title: Top Kiwi pushes for New Zealand to become an Australian state
text:
A﻿ fresh debate has erupted across the Tasman Sea over whether New Zealand should officially be adopted as Australia's seventh state.

Kiwi pollster and political commentator David Farrar re-ignited ﻿the longstanding discussion and said it was high time New Zealand took up the 125-year-old invitation to become part of Australia.

Farrar wrote in an opinion piece for The Post that ﻿Aotearoa should merge with Australia in the name of security amid rising global political tensions.

Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and New Zealand Prime Minister Christopher Luxon. (Getty)

He said NZ needs to be "bigger to survive" and floated the idea of the ﻿country of 5.2 million people becoming an Australian colony.

"Joining Australia will protect New Zealand, enhance Australia and benefit us all," Farrar wrote.

The writer claimed the Trump administration has threatened the old world order﻿, a reference to Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney's speech at the NATO meeting in Davos.

"The rules-based order is gone, and is not returning," Farrar added.

Should New Zealand become an Australian state? Yes 529 No 610

"We are in an era where countries with might will do what they see as right for them."

Farrar's suggestion is not far-fetched – Australia's constitution actually states that New Zealand may be admitted into Australia as a state.

The Commonwealth colony of NZ also participated in early Federation conferences before it was deemed an independent state.

There is also a reciprocal agreement ﻿which allows NZ residents to visit, live and work in Australia without a tourist or work visa, and vice versa.

READ MORE: Thousands back push to memorialise Bondi victim Matilda at playground

Farrar argued New Zealand needs to be "bigger to survive". (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

However, it appears many Kiwi residents aren't chuffed with the idea.

The opinion piece quickly triggered similar articles arguing against New Zealand becoming an Australian state.

Conservative political commentator Liam Hehir said the country's political independence is not something that should be traded away and argued the country's national identity is something to be preserved.

"If independence is to end, it will end because it has become impossible to sustain, not because a cost-benefit analysis shows we might do better as someone else's state," he wrote.

"Until then, the task is not to redesign ourselves, but to do our very best to adapt and thrive giving up as little about ourselves as possible."

READ MORE: Scorching heat and high winds trigger extreme fire danger warnings

There is also a reciprocal agreement ﻿which allows NZ residents to visit, live and work in Australia without a tourist or work visa. (Getty Images/iStockphoto)

Another piece from The Post noted that any desire from New Zealand to join Australia would likely be "unrequited".﻿

A survey launched by Stuff also found 56 per cent of its readers oppose the idea.

NZ Prime Minister Christopher Luxon immediately ruled out the idea of abandoning sovereignty.

"This won't be happening," a spokesperson from his office told The Post .

"New Zealand values our close relationship with Australia, but we also value our unique national identity and our sovereignty."

title: Aussies warned to brace for more interest rate pain after RBA hike
text:
Australian borrowers have been warned to expect even more mortgage pain in the coming months after yesterday's interest rate hike .

The Reserve Bank's monetary policy board unanimously decided to raise the cash rate by 25 basis points, up to 3.85 per cent, at its first meeting of the year, in a move widely expected by economists.

In her press conference following the decision, RBA Governor Michele Bullock would not be drawn on whether future hikes were likely.

READ MORE: AI bot says it would kill a human to avoid shutdown ﻿

Some economists have warned Australians to expect another interest rate hike this year. (Getty)

"It is not the same as the tightening cycle when we were coming out of COVID, when we were coming from a 0.1 per cent cash rate; it was quite clear that we had to go up and we had to go up quickly," she told reporters.

"This isn't as clear."

Others aren't as circumspect.

Commonwealth Bank has now changed its interest rate outlook for the year, joining NAB in pencilling in a hike to 4.10 per cent in May.

READ MORE: Big four banks all pass on RBA rate hike ﻿

The RBA's updated forecasts now have inflation remaining above the 2-3 per cent target until mid-next year, while core inflation isn't predicted to reach the middle of that band until 2028.

CBA head of Australian economics Belinda Allen said that "will not be tolerated by the RBA".

"The risk always sat with a second rate hike to bring inflation back towards target and the economy back into balance," she wrote.

"With the labour market now in a better position than a few months ago, and an increased resolve from the RBA, on the balance of probabilities we now see the RBA hiking again in May to take the cash rate to 4.10 per cent.

READ MORE: New push for tradies to stop work in extreme heat ﻿

Reserve Bank Governor Michele Bullock, as always, refused to provide forward guidance about where rates are heading.. (Louie Douvis)

"But it remains a line-ball decision and is dependent on the data flow from here."

The remaining two big four banks – Westpac and ANZ – are tipping interest rates will remain on hold for the rest of the year, although both have admitted there is a risk of another hike.

"The low bar for further hikes means that, (without) a downside surprise in the March quarter inflation outcome, the monetary policy board is likely to hike again in May," Westpac chief economist Luci Ellis said.

In a further blow to the likelihood of inflation cooling off quicker – and potentially avoiding the RBA pushing up rates again – new research from non-profit the e61 Institute showed yesterday's rate increase may not do much to slow down rising prices.

"Raising rates may not have a large impact on consumer spending in the near term," research director Dr Gianni La Cava said.

READ MORE: More than a million homeowners struggling to pay mortgage ﻿

While it's not known whether the RBA will hand down another hike, any chance of lower rates is well and truly gone. (Tony Yoo)

"We found that when the RBA hiked rates by 4.25 percentage points over 2022 and 2023, people with variable mortgages barely changed their spending habits despite payments rising by $14,000 a year on average.

"This was because they could mostly finance the extra payments from large savings held in offset and redraw accounts.

"Those savings absorbed the shock, letting many households preserve their lifestyles despite higher interest costs.

"In late 2025, households still had significant buffers in their offset and redraw accounts, with 40 per cent of mortgage holders holding enough savings to make minimum payments for two years.

"This indicates that the latest interest rate rise will likely have a limited impact on spending through the cash flow channel."

title: 'Silent strain': More than a million homeowners struggling to pay mortgage
text:
N﻿ew research shows more than a million mortgage holders were struggling with repayments before the Reserve Bank of Australia lifted the cash rate yesterday .

One in three homeowners – equivalent to 1,155,000 people – said they struggled to pay their mortgage in January, according to a survey by comparison site Finder released today.

It comes after the the official cash rate was yesterday increased by 25 basis points to 3.85 per cent, the first hike in two years﻿.

READ MORE: Big four banks all pass on RBA rate hike

The interest rate hike is putting further financial stress on Aussie households. (Getty)

Australia's big four banks have all moved to raise variable interest home loan rates .

To gain any relief from financial stress, the average borrower would need their interest rate to drop to 4.6 per cent, the Finder research found.

It also revealed 12 per cent of borrowers say they have missed at least one mortgage repayment in the past six months.

﻿The rates hike also added to the gloomy outlook of Australians seeking to buy their first home, with 36 per cent believing they'll never take a first step on the property ladder.

Yesterday's rate hike will add about $100 to an average mortgage holder's minimum monthly repayments, although many borrowers have a buffer built up thanks to last year's three cuts.

Finder home loans expert Richard Whitten says the small rise in interest rates could push thousands of borrowers further into financial stress﻿.

"Many ﻿households are already cutting back on spending just to keep up with their home loans – it's a silent strain on families," he said.

"And the cost of living has continued to rise. So rising loan repayments only add to the strain."

"Now is the time to explore your mortgage options before stress turns into a crisis."

title: Jess and Allan chose a 116,000km trip over a mortgage and have no regrets
text:
Five years ago, as the COVID-19 pandemic raged on , Allan Mercer and Jess Smith reached a fork in the road.

The South Australian couple realised they had two options: pursue the white picket fence dream and buy a house, or leave it all behind to live permanently on the road.

Naturally, the pair of "not-so-grey" nomads chose the latter.

﻿Mercer, 41, and Smith, 32, sold almost everything they owned, gave up their three-bedroom rental and decked out a campervan to permanently explore Australia.

Allan and Jess quit their jobs to travel full-time around Australia. (Supplied)

Around ﻿116,000 kilometres later, they have no plans to ever return to their old lives.

"﻿We were both working normal jobs," Mercer told nine.com.au.

"Jess is a physiotherapist by trade, and at the time, I was running my own personal training business, which was doing well."﻿

The couple often worked six-day weeks and grew weary of the rat race.

And while plenty of their friends and family members back home knuckled down to buy a house, Mercer and Smith wanted something more.

They didn't want to wait until retirement to see their own backyard.﻿

"We hardly ever got to go away. We never really had weekends," Mercer added.

"We kind of got sick of paying somebody else's mortgage for their house.

"While we were sort of saving money, it wasn't enough to be able to get out of the rent cycle."

The South Australian couple decided to avoid a mortgage for life on the the road. (Supplied)

Mercer said he "pestered" his now-fiancee to take the leap.

"One particular day, Jess actually just turned around and said, 'Yep, let's do it'," he recalled.

After ending their lease and holding a garage sale, the couple set off ﻿for an indefinite trip alongside Mercer's parents, who also live on the road full-time.

Smith said her own parents were a little "shocked" by their decision﻿.

"They [asked me], but you've got a partner, why don't you buy a house?" she laughed.

Aged in their 20s and 30s when they embarked on their adventure, Mercer and Smith are among tens of thousands of younger Australians who are eschewing mortgages for life on the road.

An Australian Facebook group known as " Not Grey Nomads ﻿" has over 300,000 members and counting.

Around ﻿116,000 kilometres later, they have no plans of ever returning to their old lives. (Supplied)

﻿Half a decade and a trove of priceless ﻿experiences later, Mercer and Smith have no regrets about buying a van instead of a property.

They have travelled ﻿to almost every state and territory in Australia except the ACT.

Their dream life has taken them to WA's Pilbara, Fortescue Bay in Tasmania, the Nullabor Plain, SA's Flinders Ranges, Rottnest Island, Bundaberg and Uluru.

"We've definitely done the coin toss before to decide which way to go," Mercer said.

﻿"I like being spontaneous now, I can deal with not having an exact plan for where we are going," Smith added.

Right now, they are slowly making their way through Victoria's High Country.

When it gets colder, the couple will migrate north to "follow the sun".﻿

The pair sometimes toss a coin to decide where they will go next. (Supplied)

Finances can be the most difficult part of full-time travel.

Smith still keeps her ﻿registration as a physio by taking on casual appointments wherever they travel, and they both pick up odd jobs at pubs, caravan parks or bottle shops in small towns to earn cash.

"The most it's ever taken us to find work over five years is two days," Mercer said.

They also run a popular YouTube channel and Instagram page called ExploreOz , which they hope can earn them full-time income.﻿

It can cost between $500 to $1000 per week to live on the road.

That includes petrol, van maintenance, internet bills, ﻿flat tyres, food and campsite fees.

Diesel petrol for their ﻿2023 Isuzu D-Max is the biggest expense that eats into their budget.

"We're spending a lot less money per week now compared to what we would be spending ﻿on a mortgage," Mercer added.

Mercer and Smith have no intention of ending their travels and say it's possible to live on the road "forever".

"We still get a lot of, 'How's your trip going? How's your holiday?" Mercer said.

"But this is our life now. This is what we do."﻿

title: Queensland government's plan to boost housing draws criticism
text:
The Queensland government is selling off state-owned land to developers, in a bid to boost housing supply.

Today, Deputy Premier Jarrod Bleijie started the state-wide sale with a 400-home development on Brisbane's northside.

But the new developer-driven housing scheme has drawn criticism from local residents and housing advocates alike.

READ MORE: ﻿ Fears homes may have been lost as bushfires rage in South Australia

The Queensland government is trying to boost housing supply but a 400-home development in Brisbane's north has drawn criticism from residents and housing advocates alike. (9News)

The scheme's effectively a land sale program, unlocking under-utilised state-owned land for private development.

The first parcel, a six-hectare block in Banyo, will go from a former Energex depot to 400 new homes.

"We are serious about supply, supply, supply and we're serious about partnering with the private sector," Bleijie said.

"When government and industry work in lockstep, we can actually deliver things faster."

But Queensland Council of Social Service chief executive Aimee McVeigh had questions over affordability.

Deputy Premier Jarrod Bleijie started the state-wide sale, with a 400-home development on Brisbane's northside. (9News)

"The concern is, that this plan won't deliver more social and affordable housing for Queenslanders, which is so sorely needed," she said.

Local residents are also critical, claiming they weren't consulted and calling for better infrastructure in the area.

"[I'm] happy to see it developed and it needs to be developed but now they're talking high density, 400 housing, the streets just can't handle it," neighbouring resident Keith Bitossi told 9News.

The scheme's effectively a land sale program, unlocking under-utilised state-owned land for private development. (9News)

Fellow resident Chris Vale agreed.

"The infrastructure for roads, stormwater and sewer just cannot handle what we've got now," he said.

Criticism aside, the deputy premier is expected to announce further sites across the state in coming days and the land sales won't stop there.

Under the new scheme, developers can also register interest in public land not already earmarked for sale.

Local residents are critical, claiming they weren't consulted and calling for better infrastructure in the area. (9News)

The government stresses it isn't about selling land for the right price, it's "about land activation and housing supply".

But opposition spokesman for state development Cameron Dick isn't buying it.

"This LNP plan is a big win for property developer and a massive loss for Queenslanders seeking to put a roof over their own head," he said.

title: Big four banks all pass on RBA rate hike
text:
Australia's big four banks have all moved to pass on the Reserve Bank of Australia 's interest rate hike .

The official cash rate was today increased by 25 basis points to 3.85 per cent , the first hike in two years.

Westpac was the first to announce that it would raise its variable interest home loan rates by 0.25 per cent but the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, National Australia Bank and ANZ quickly followed suit.

AS IT HAPPENED: Reserve Bank announces rate hike﻿

The official cash rate has risen by 0.25 basis points to a total of 3.85 per cent. (Dominic Lorrimer)

Westpac's changes will take effect from February 17 while the other banks will shift on the 13th.

Today's hike will add around $100 to an average mortgage holder's monthly repayments , although many borrowers have a buffer built up thanks to last year's three cuts.

The central bank's updated economic forecasts didn't bode well for borrowers, with inflation not predicted to come back into the 2 to 3 per cent target band until June 2027, and core inflation not tipped to reach the middle of that range for a further year.

But Governor Michele Bullock seemed genuinely unsure about what her bank's next move will be.

"It is not the same as the tightening cycle when we were coming out of COVID, when we were coming from 0.1 per cent cash rate; it was quite clear that we had to go up and we had to go up quickly," she said.

"This isn't as clear."﻿

CBA's economists expect another hike in May, taking the cash rate to 4.1 per cent, because there's unlikely to be enough evidence by then to show today's hike is slowing demand.﻿

"Inflation is simply too high for the RBA at this stage, and the central bank has signalled a stronger resolve to bring it back within target," Commonwealth Bank head of Australian economics Belinda Allen said.

NAB chief economist Sally Auld suspected this was unlikely to be a "one-and-done" scenario for the RBA.

Financial comparison site Canstar also warned homeowners to prepare for the possibility of future rate hikes while noting the banks' silence on savings.

"None of the big four banks have said anything about savings rates – creating an unfortunate waiting game that keeps loyal savers in the dark," data insights director Sally Tindall said.

"A climbing cash rate can be good news for steadfast savers, but know that banks often hand-pick which rates go up and which ones miss out."

Investors ramped up bets for a follow-up hike in May, which is now priced about 75 per cent. Markets expect an additional total tightening of 40 basis points this year.

The RBA joins the Bank of Japan as the only other developed-world central bank tightening policy at the moment. Markets are still priced for rate cuts in the US, UK and Canada, while the European Central Bank is widely expected to be on an extended pause.

Markets had wagered on a 78 per cent probability of a hike given inflation surprised on the high side in the fourth quarter, while unemployment hit a seven-month low in December.

The Australian dollar extended earlier gains to be up 0.9 per cent to $US0.7002 while three-year government bond yields jumped 8 basis points to 4.3 per cent.

The RBA did not raise interest rates as aggressively as its international peers when inflation was running hot due to its desire to preserve gains in the labour market.

That approach may yet test policymakers. The central bank's three rate cuts last year saw inflation rear its head again, forcing it to pivot towards a hawkish stance late in 2025 and prompting market bets of an earlier-than-expected start to the tightening cycle.

- reported with Reuters ﻿

title: Construction workers narrowly avoid falling scaffolding on Sydney job site
text:
More than a tonne of scaffolding narrowly missed a group of construction workers as it plummeted more than 20 storeys in Sydney 's north this morning.

Dashcam from shortly after 8am today captured workers jumping out of the way to avoid the falling load.

The crash zone off Talavera Road at Macquarie Park was fenced off today, with crane work halted as its steel wire ropes remain buckled below.

Dashcam from just after 8am today capturing the load of scaffolding narrowly missing this worker who jumps out of the way. (2GB)

SafeWork NSW is now looking into the incident to determine whether human error or mechanical failure played a role. (Nine)

Workers were seen getting stuck back in to work, though the focus remains on what caused the failure.

"Urban is proud of its safety record and will conduct a full investigation into this matter," Urban Property General Manager Nick Gaudry told 9News in a statement.

SafeWork NSW is looking into the incident to determine whether human error or mechanical failure played a role, and if it was preventable.

title: Waterski racing event cancelled amid permit issues
text:
A waterski racing event in South Australia's Riverland has been cancelled after organisers said they would not be able to meet the necessary permit requirements.

It comes as South Australia's Department for Infrastructure and Transport (DIT) and the sport's peak body, Ski Racing Australia, previously confirmed the event was unsanctioned.

The event — organised by a group called Riverland Water Ski Racing SA and promoted on Facebook in early December — was scheduled to take place at Lake Bonney on February 7 and 8.

It had 17 races scheduled, with some set to feature racers being towed by powerboats at speeds of up to 144 km/h.

Some of the proposed events were set to reach speeds of up to 144km/h (90mph). (Source: Riverland Water Ski SA lake race format)

The event promoted entry fees of $350 per boat and $300 per participant on its Facebook page, with 130 participants across 27 boats confirmed to take part as of January 21.

But in a social media post, Riverland Water Ski Racing SA said Marine Safety SA had "presented a late list of permit conditions" that was not "feasible to meet" so close to the event taking place.

Event organisers say they will be refunding participants who had already entered. (Source: Riverland Water Ski Racing SA)

'Further clarification' required

In a statement, a DIT spokesperson confirmed it had still been reviewing an application from the organisers for an aquatic activity licence when it was notified of the event's cancellation.

The department said it had reached out to receive "further clarification and documentation from the organiser" as part of its assessment process.

"We had been undertaking a detailed review of the application ... to determine whether sufficient assurance was provided that risks to participants, officials and other river users could be adequately managed," the DIT spokesperson said.

The department told the ABC it had received an aquatic activity licence application from Riverland Water Ski Racing SA on January 16 — two weeks ahead of the event taking place.

The department requires applications for such a licence to be submitted "no less than four weeks before an event", and at least four weeks' notice is required to "ensure the licence can be issued before the event".

DIT requested "further clarification and documentation from the organiser". (Source: Riverland Water Ski Racing SA proposed race course)

Riverland Water Ski Racing SA did not provide answers to questions from the ABC about the cancellation of the event.

In its social media post earlier this week, it stated "all paid memberships will be refunded" while it works on getting the event "back on the water".

Racing under review

The national body, Ski Racing Australia, is currently undertaking a broader review of its risk management framework following the suspension of racing events in 2024.

The review recommended the prohibition of all water ski racing on river courses and a permanently-imposed speed limit of 110km/h on all towing activities.

DIT said outcomes of the review, which was undertaken by the NSW Government, are "expected to inform future ski racing events".

DIT says it will be monitoring Lake Bonney this weekend. (ABC Riverland: Sophie Landau)

The department confirmed its staff would be operating in the Riverland this weekend to ensure compliance was upheld on Lake Bonney.

"Marine Safety Officers will be present in the Riverland over the weekend to monitor activity and enforce compliance, including speed limits and other safety requirements, to help ensure the safety of all waterway users," it said.

title: Diamonds eye timely glimpse of Jamaica in Test series
text:
Australia's netballers expect to gain precious intelligence ahead of a showpiece tournament when they host Jamaica in a three-Test series.

The world number one Diamonds meet Jamaica in the first Test in Adelaide on Thursday night — a rematch of the 2022 Commonwealth Games gold-medal game.

Australia won that clash, and with another Commonwealth Games looming in Scotland from late July, the Test series will provide coach Stacey Marinkovich's side with a timely glimpse of the world number three Jamaicans.

Diamonds bolster defence for Jamaica series Australia's netball hierarchy settles on a replacement for an injured defender ahead of the Diamonds' three-Test series against Jamaica.

But it will be just a glimpse rather than an in-depth look, with Jamaica resting a batch of stars, including shooters Jhaniele Fowler-Nembhard and Romelda Aiken-George.

"You still prepare the same way," Diamonds defender Matilda Garrett told reporters on Wednesday.

"Obviously the list is slightly different. It's our job to make sure that we analyse every single player who you might come up against and see what each player likes to do, what channel they like to run in and things like that.

"So similar preparation as to what we would if we were playing against some of the other players that we have played against multiple times.

"It's kind of exciting to see the depth that they have in their squad, and it helps with Commonwealth Games preparation as well, because any of these girls could be selected."

Garrett was summoned into the 12-strong Diamonds squad to replace fellow defender Sunday Aryang, who tore an anterior cruciate ligament during Australia's most recent Test in October.

"Obviously it was very devastating for Sunday and also us, seeing her go down," Garrett said.

"But with netball when people do go down with injuries, it does open up opportunities, and I feel very, very grateful to be here.

"When the list came out, I did shed a few tears — I just feel super grateful to be here, and I just want to take every opportunity with two hands if I get the chance to go out and play."

After the series opener in Adelaide, the Diamonds host Jamaica in Perth on Sunday and Melbourne next Wednesday.

title: Demons defender May misses AFL pre-season training
text:
Veteran Melbourne defender Steven May was a notable absentee from training, six weeks out from the start of the AFL season.

The 2021 premiership defender will be a restricted free agent at the end of this season.

May was a key figure in last year's trade period, but failed to find a new home.

The Demons have been contacted for comment after May was not at Wednesday morning's training session.

Off the field, May and Richmond midfielder Dion Prestia are fighting criminal charges after a late-2024 brawl in Sorrento on Victoria's Mornington Peninsula.

Last month, the pair asked for the charges to be withdrawn, saying they were not there.

They are due to face Frankston Magistrates Court again on February 20.

May, 34, played 16 senior games last year for a career total of 251. He endured a mixed season, serving a three-match ban for a high bump, and also had Hawthorn veteran Jack Gunston kick a bag of seven on him.

The Demons are in major transition, with coach Simon Goodwin sacked last year and Steven King appointed for his first senior role.

Star onballers Christian Petracca (Gold Coast) and Clayton Oliver (GWS) were traded after last season.

title: Defence to sell prime Perth riverside land to help pay for AUKUS
text:
Dozens of hectares of prime residential land in Perth's leafy western suburbs and along the Swan River will be sold off amid a shake up of the Australian Defence property portfolio.

The federal government has announced plans to either fully or partially sell 67 defence sites across the nation in the hopes of freeing up around $1.8 billion for bases in Australia's north and the AUKUS submarine pact.

In Western Australia, the Defence Department plans to sell off its main Army Reserve site at Irwin Barracks, which sits on a 61.5-hectare site in Karrakatta.

As many as 1,150 reservists are expected to be impacted by the move, with the department anticipating their work will move to Palmer Barracks in South Guildford once the site is sold.

About 200 Australian Defence Force personnel and 250 cadets would also be affected by the move.

The government will also try to sell Leeuwin Barracks, which sits on 14-hectares of prime riverfront land in East Fremantle, for a second time after a bid in 2015 fell over.

The government has tried to sell Leeuwin Barracks before, without success. (ABC News: Jessica Strutt)

About 250 cadets will be the largest group affected by the move, as well as up to 150 reservists, 100 public service staff and 50 ADF personnel.

New facilities at Palmer Barracks

Defence Personnel Minister and WA MP Matt Keogh said the process would now begin to start moving people from both bases.

Defence Personnel Minister Matt Keogh says Palmer Barracks will be turned into "the ongoing base in the Perth metro area". (ABC News: Courtney Withers)

"There will be quite a bit of construction work that will need to happen with new, state-of-the-art facilities to go into Palmer Barracks which will provide a consolidated site, near the airport, good transport links, to be the ongoing base in the Perth metro area, if you like, to support our predominantly reservist forces," he told ABC Radio Perth.

"And then once that's ready to go those defence force members, public servants, will move to that site, and then Irwin and Leeuwin will be able to be divested."

Mr Keogh said while across the nation Defence land would end up being used for a "wide variety" of purposes, it would be fair to say some would be turned into housing.

Government to sell historic defence properties The Albanese government has identified 67 defence sites for potential sale, aiming to unlock up to $1.8 billion.

A Defence fact sheet about plans for WA says final decisions about personnel movements will be made "following consultation".

Changes in regional WA

The government says all proceeds from land sales will be retained and reinvested by Defence.

The importance of strengthening the nation's northern bases was highlighted in the 2023 Defence Strategic Review, which described Western Australia's northern coast in particular as a "primary area of military interest".

Not only is it likely the nation's first line of defence against any potential attack, but the region is also home to much of the nation's mining and resources industry,

Army cadets are likely to be most affected by the closure of Leeuwin Barracks. (ABC News: Charlotte Hamlyn)

The audit which recommended the government's planned sell off also called for an "integrated strategy" for all Defence facilities in the Exmouth region.

The Commonwealth agreed to that recommendation, committing to create an "integrated strategy for the Exmouth region aligned with the Defence Strategic Review" and a plan to manage the area as an "integrated regional precinct".

The shake up is also expected to see the government ends its lease of two regional rife ranges near Busselton and Karratha.

title: Child abuse survivors want paedophile pay-out loopholes tightened
text:
Edan van Haren was 14 in 2010, when a pattern of repeated sexual abuse began at the home of former Bega Cheese boss Maurice Van Ryn, on the far south coast of New South Wales.

Five years later, Van Ryn was jailed for 13 years for abusing nine boys and girls since 2003.

In July 2023, after initially being offered $25,000 by Van Ryn's legal team, the now 29-year-old Mr van Haren was awarded $1.4 million in damages by the NSW Supreme Court.

His abuser has since declared bankruptcy, using a legal loophole that extinguishes the victim payment while protecting assets in superannuation, and the Adelaide resident is yet to see a cent of the money.

"It made me feel abused and manipulated, and like the world just wanted victims to keep losing," he said.

Eden van Haren was a teenager when he fell victim to child predator Maurice Van Ryn. (Supplied: Van Haren family)

The federal government is considering changes to superannuation and bankruptcy laws that would help survivors access their abuser's retirement savings if the perpetrators fail to pay court-ordered compensation.

The draft law would let survivors apply to the Australian Taxation Office for information about their abuser's superannuation accounts and seek the release of money to meet unpaid compensation orders.

The proposed changes would also see compensation debts survive if abusers declare bankruptcy to avoid paying their victims.

The payments would be limited to certain types of super contributions made from the time the abuse began, including personal contributions, and extra employer contributions not legally required.

Mr van Haren welcomed the government's attempt to close the loopholes, but said the draft legislation contained "a few errors".

"I think all super should be available to victims, not just … additional contributions," he said.

"If the government doesn't get this right, then you end up with a cycle where there are all these victims that don't end up having their own super in the long run because they haven't been able to maintain a job.

" It just makes the victims suffer and not the paedophiles. "

Andrew Carpenter says the draft legislation does not go far enough. (ABC News: Ashlin Blieschke)

Mr van Haren's lawyer, Andrew Carpenter, said the proposed legislation did not go far enough.

"The original pitch to the government that we made was that it should be for all victim-survivors of child abuse, regardless of [an abuser's] conviction or not," he said.

"The many people who succeed with civil actions should have it available to them, because if a judge makes a ruling that the abuse occurred and someone is awarded damages, why shouldn't they be able to access the superannuation of the offenders?

" This means that the taxpayer is going to continue to indemnify the sins of these offenders, and the offenders can simply enjoy their retirement and their millions of dollars of superannuation. "

Mr Carpenter said it took on average more than two decades for victim-survivors to report abuse.

"By that time evidence dries up, witnesses pass away and it is very hard to get a conviction with the passing of that time," he said.

"However in the civil sphere, offenders don't usually enjoy the right to silence and have to take part in the civil action and subject themselves to cross-examination."

Attorney-General Michelle Rowland announced the public consultation period on Monday. (ABC News: Matt Roberts)

Jason Harris, professor of corporate law at Sydney University, said the reforms were a step in the right direction.

"One thing that is unfortunate is that the period of consultation is only a few weeks, and there are no doubt complexities in these proposals and how they will slot into the tax and bankruptcy system," he said.

"So they will need to be fully considered to make sure that the proposals are going to achieve the victims' goals and help provide them with realistic avenues of compensation.

" Often when the government has a very short consultation period, it's because they have already made up their mind. "

A spokesperson from the office of Assistant Treasurer and Minister for Financial Services Daniel Mulino said the bill was likely to pass parliament over the next few months.

title: SA government offers low-interest drought loans to farmers
text:
South Australian farmers under financial strain from years of drought will be able to access low-interest loans of up to $250,000 from the state government.

The $200-million program will be made available to drought-affected farmers in some of SA's worst-hit regions — the Murray Mallee, Riverland and Upper North.

It follows months of calls from farmers and industry groups for the government to offer no or low-interest loans to those whose finances have been significantly impacted in recent years by some of the worst drought conditions on record.

SA Premier Peter Malinauskas says the new loan program adds to drought support measures previously announced by the government. (ABC News: Sophie Holder)

Premier Peter Malinauskas deemed the measure necessary due to an "unprecedented" situation.

"This is not what state governments normally do," he said.

"If I'm honest about it, some of our treasury officials are worried about setting the precedent, but some of the conditions that some of the farmers are facing are unprecedented, which is why ultimately I made the judgement that this response was necessary.

"We don't want to see good farmers missing out on access to cashflow at critical times around seeding, that then potentially could set them up for years ahead."

The SA Drought Loan Scheme comes in addition to $97-million drought assistance measures previously announced by the state government.

Farmers struggling with finances

Emily Morgan, who farms in Jabuk in the Murray Mallee, says farmers have been asking for such a measure "for a very long time".

Emily Morgan, a farmer from Jabuk in SA's Mallee, has advocated for low-interest loans. (Supplied: Emily Morgan)

"We would have loved to have heard about this a year and a half ago, but look, it's a really positive announcement," she said.

"We really struggled when the drought hit with inputs, really struggled to pay for hay, for fertiliser, for fuel — and the government's package at the time didn't really match what we actually needed, which was a low-interest loan.

"We run legitimate businesses and when we face tough times we need the ability to be able to pause our interest and principal repayments so we can recover — and when we recover and [get] back in the swing of things, we're able to repay.

" We're not asking for handouts or charity — we're asking for the ability to continue to run our business. "

Industry group Grain Producers SA (GPSA) proposed the loan scheme to the state government throughout the drought.

Chief executive Brad Perry said it was essential drought-affected farmers got access to the loans quickly to ensure crops could be planted this year.

Farmers won't have to start repaying the new loans for the first two years, in which time it's hoped their situation will improve. (ABC News: Emily Doak)

"They've done everything they can in their power, but if it doesn't rain you can't grow crop," he said.

"They're really struggling and talking about only being able to put in a quarter or less of their crop this season.

"What we want is for this loan to be able to help them get back on their feet, get through these seasons to when it does rain again, and they can get back to some normality, we keep these good farmers in the industry, and we don't lose generations of farmers."

Under the program, grain and livestock producers will be able to borrow up to $250,000 under a 10-year loan, with a two-year grace period before repayments need to be made.

The drought forced many SA farmers to either destock or invest heavily in fodder to keep their livestock fed and healthy. (ABC Rural: Selina Green)

The loans will have concessional interest rates for the first two years at 50 per cent of the Commonwealth 10-year bond rate, after which the rate will match the Commonwealth rate.

Lower interest loans on offer

Mr Malinauskas says this will be lower than the current interest rate offered by the federal government's Regional Investment Corporation (RIC) loan scheme, which sits at 5.18 per cent.

He said it had become clear the RIC's loans were not "as generous as many people in the agricultural sector would like".

Parts of SA recorded their driest conditions in 2024. (ABC Rural: Selina Green)

"Industry has made pretty clear that the adjustments that were made following the review of the RIC loans by the federal government haven't met their needs," Mr Malinauskas said.

"That's what spurred us into action to say 'listen, there are still a number of communities around the state still very adversely affected by the drought'.

"Because the federal government's program doesn't work, we're going to do our own."

title: Change to rugby league kick-off rule delayed until end of season
text:
A proposed rule change to the rugby league kick-off will not be enforced at the start of the 2026 NRL season, instead being trialled during matches later in the year.

The Australian Rugby League Commission on Wednesday announced four new on-field rule changes ahead of the new season, which begins in Las Vegas on Sunday, March 1, AEDT.

However, there was no change to the kick-off announced in the ARLC's package of approved rule adjustments.

A change to the kick-off rule had been proposed following a score, where the non-scoring team would have the option of either kicking or receiving the restart.

The ARLC announced on Wednesday the rule tweak would be trialled at the end of the season in matches "with no bearing on the finals".

"The consultation process was thorough and constructive, and while there was initial support for the kick-off proposal, stakeholders raised legitimate concerns," ARLC chairman Peter V'landys said.

"After weighing that feedback carefully, the Commission determined that it was not in the best interests of the game to proceed with that particular change at this time."

A statement from the ARLC announced four rule changes for the 2026 season:

Trainer rules — Trainers will be restricted from entering the field of play to prescribed and clearly defined circumstances. This will ensure player safety remains the priority while reducing unnecessary intrusions by trainers carrying messages.

Interchange rules — Teams may interchange four players, up to eight times per match, from a squad of six players (players 14 to 19 inclusive).

Accidental breach (zero tackle) in-goal — There will be no seven-tackle set following a knock-on in-goal by the attacking team.

Restarting the tackle count — For certain infringements beyond the 20-metre line, the tackle count will restart, replacing the current 40m threshold.

In a statement, Mr V'landys said it was hoped the changes would improve the spectacle of the game, while also adding tactical options for coaches.

"The changes that are being implemented are intended to build on the success of the 2025 season by enhancing the entertainment value for fans, while also providing additional tactical options for coaches.

"The game is in a brilliant place. The players are producing incredible feats and the fans are responding. These changes will enhance the game further and continue to ensure this is the best and most watched sport in the country."

title: Measles case in person who hadn't travelled 'very much a concern'
text:
South Australia's health department says undetected measles is circulating in Adelaide, after an infection was identified in someone who had not recently travelled.

SA Health said the adult acquired the infection locally, with chief public health officer Nicola Spurrier describing the case as "very much a concern".

SA Health has released a list of possible exposure sites — including trams, food venues, a swimming centre and the BHP building in the CBD — that were attended by the adult while infectious.

Professor Spurrier said measles was "highly contagious" and can have potentially severe consequences.

She said while measles was always concerning, cases in recent years had typically been in people who had travelled overseas.

"In this particular case that we've had notified, they have not travelled, they haven't travelled interstate, they haven't been on a plane and they haven't been overseas and that means we've got undetected measles circulating in Adelaide, which is really very much a concern to us," she told ABC Radio Adelaide.

"We've been for such a long time in a measles-free state, in a way.

"Measles is highly contagious — it's one of the most contagious infectious diseases and it can also have very severe complications and in fact one of those is brain infection or encephalitis."

Professor Spurrier said contact tracing had been undertaken.

SA Health said the measles case visited the following locations while infectious, and that people who were there at the same time might have been exposed:

January 26: Unley Swimming Centre, Ethel St, Forestville, 4pm to 6:30pm

Unley Swimming Centre, Ethel St, Forestville, 4pm to 6:30pm January 27: 9:42am Adelaide Metro Tram from Forestville to Royal Adelaide Hospital

9:42am Adelaide Metro Tram from Forestville to Royal Adelaide Hospital 10:11am Adelaide Metro Tram from Royal Adelaide Hospital to South Terrace

BHP, 10 Franklin Street Adelaide, on 27 January, 9:45am to 5:30pm

Rolls n Rice, 6/118 King William Street, Adelaide, 12:45pm to 1:30pm

48 Flavours, 248 Unley Road, Hyde Park, 5pm to 6:00pm

The BHP office on King William Street in Adelaide is on the list of possible exposure sites. (ABC News: Eugene Boisvert)

SA Health advised anyone not fully immunised, and who attended those locations at those times, "to be alert for symptoms over the next few weeks and to see a doctor if they become ill".

But it urged people who suspected they could have measles to phone their doctor beforehand and tell them why they were intending to attend, "so precautions can be taken to avoid spreading disease to others".

"Once it's in the air and the person leaves, it can actually hang around for about 30 minutes," Professor Spurrier said.

"When you're in an enclosed space — if it's in the change room, for example, it's an enclosed space — then it is highly contagious."

SA Health said the latest case is the second notified in South Australia this year, and it has recommended people ensure they are vaccinated with two doses.

"With measles … you're actually infectious a day before you get the symptoms, and you start off with symptoms which are a cough and a bit of runny nose," Professor Spurrier said.

"It becomes more obvious when, about four days later, you get a rash."

title: Metro Trains boss, premier apologise for chaos on peak hour services
text:
Melbourne's rail service provider and the premier have both apologised to passengers who were trapped in hot carriages for hours after a fault halted services running through the new Metro Tunnel on Tuesday evening.

Thousands of peak hour commuters were disrupted when an overhead power fault at Armadale halted peak-hour trains on the newly re-routed Cranbourne, Pakenham and Sunbury lines just days after full services began running through the new tunnel.

About 600 passengers were stuck on board two trains without air-conditioning for up to to two hours in 30 degree Celsius heat before they could be evacuated from their carriages and walked along the line to their nearest station in Malvern.

Other services were cancelled during the chaos and after the fault was fixed, including services from Caulfield through the Metro Tunnel and out to West Footscray for the rest of Tuesday night.

Passengers had to walk to Malvern station after being helped off a stationary train. (Supplied: Britney Burgess)

Metro Trains CEO Raymond O'Flaherty said the shutdown was caused by an overhead wire and pantograph — the apparatus mounted on the roof of a train that connects to the powerline — becoming entangled.

He said he apologised to all Melbourne commuters.

"I know it was incredibly frustrating and took a lot of extra time for them to make their journeys," Mr O'Flaherty told ABC Radio Melbourne.

"Particularly, I want to apologise to the 600 passengers that were on board the two trains that were stuck on the network for one-and-a-half to two hours while we went through a safe method to de-train them.

" They deserve better. "

Raymond O'Flaherty inside the Parkville station when the Metro Tunnel opened in November. (ABC News)

Mr O'Flaherty defended the amount of time it took to get the passengers off the sweltering carriages.

"Because of where the incident occurred between two stations on a live track, it was a very complex environment," he said.

"We had trains running on adjacent lines, we had electrical wires that came down and were on top of the trains.

"Because we were very nervous making sure that everybody would be safe, that no-one would be electrocuted, that's why it took us that 90 minutes to two hours before we could get people off the trains."

He said passengers were directed onto alternative City Loop trains and replacement buses.

"It was inconvenient, but having the City Loop … did give us that backup, we were able to get people onto trains."

Metro Trains says crews had to make sure it was safe before passengers could walk to to Malvern station. (Supplied: Britney Burgess)

Transport and technology journalist Jeremy Burge was heading into the city on a City Loop train last night when he heard about the Metro Tunnel disruptions.

"Being a transport nerd, [I] walked to State Library to see how the first major disruption to the Metro Tunnel was being handled," he said.

Mr Burge said the screens that displayed service and schedule information were still indicating that trains were running as normal, half an hour after the lines were shut down.

"I saw staff frantically trying to stop people heading down to the platforms, because if you were transferring at Melbourne Central you'd look at the screen and it would say, 'Train in five minutes or 10 minutes' and that was not true," he said.

"That was definitely the source of confusion."

He said there was no signage directing passengers to instead take a City Loop train.

"Passenger information displays were also not updated for about 40 minutes or so.

"Staff were having to verbally tell people to turn around."

Jacinta Allan says the fault and display of wrong passenger information would be investigated. (ABC News)

Premier Jacinta Allan on Wednesday joined Metro Trains in apologising to commuters.

"I'd like to acknowledge and apologise to those passengers who had a really difficult experience last night," she said.

Ms Allan said investigations into the cause of the fault were underway, and there would also be a probe into what went wrong with passenger information screens.

"It's not the experience that we want passengers on any part of our train network to have."

Metro Tunnel big switch New timetables are being rolled out across Melbourne's train network, with more than 1,200 extra weekly services commencing from today.

The state opposition has accused the government of failing to prepare Melbourne's train network for high capacity metro trains (HCMT).

Shadow Minister for Public Transport Matthew Guy said the existing infrastructure could not support the city's new trains.

"This is like an Apple iPhone but the system is built … with a battery that can manage Nokia phones."

The routes of the Cranbourne, Pakenham and Sunbury lines changed as part of the Metro Tunnel project and on Sunday began running at full capacity every three to four minutes through the underground stations.

Metro Trains said it would consider whether affected passengers would receive compensation in the coming weeks.

title: No plans to increase security at Wittenoom after blogger's 'devastating' visit
text:
Authorities say they have no plans to increase security or patrols around one of Western Australia's most heavily contaminated landscapes, despite a popular travel video blogger showing just how easy it is to access.

Wittenoom, 1,600 kilometres north of Perth, was home to Australia's biggest industrial disaster, with the former town's asbestos mines linked to an estimated 4,000 deaths.

After years of deliberation and planning, demolition work at the Wittenoom town began in 2023. (Supplied)

The town was closed and buildings demolished by the WA government due to the risks.

But Queensland mum Ronelle Fotinis said she was drawn to visiting the former town as part of her fascination with places "out of the norm".

Ronelle and her daughter plan to continue their travels around Australia in the next few years. (Supplied: Facebook)

Her curiosity led her to Wittenoom late last year, filming and posting videos to social media and her YouTube channel Adventure Life Oz.

But her decision to bring her four-year-old daughter to her visit has been heavily criticised by asbestos disease advocates.

'It only takes one visit'

Asbestos Disease Society of Australia chief executive Melita Markey says you cannot take back an asbestos exposure.

"It's devastating, as a parent, as a mother," Ms Markey said of the visit.

"I think it just comes down to people making that choice of risk. People are attracted to risk. But where I feel that it's wrong is that they are putting their attitude to risk onto their children.

" We do have teenagers with mesothelioma in this country. "

Melita Markey, CEO of the Asbestos Diseases Society of Australia (ABC News: Nicholas Martyr)

Ms Markey said people did not need to be in the town long to inhale deadly crocidolite fibres that were invisible to the naked eye.

While the asbestos mine was closed in 1966, the town continued to operate for decades, with the school open until 1985 and the Wittenoom races held until 1991.

Jockeys who attended the circuit fewer than five times have since succumbed to asbestos-related diseases, with Wittenoom their only known contamination.

Crowds gather at Wittenoom Race Course in 1970, despite the asbestos mine closing in 1966. (Supplied: State Library of Western Australia)

Attention despite safety risks

Despite the serious risks posed by visiting the site, a small but steady stream of travellers continues to dice with both a physical and financial penalty.

But the WA government does not plan to take any further action to restrict access.

In a statement, the Department of Planning, Lands and Heritage said access remained prohibited, and could incur a $500 fine.

Wittenoom sits next to picturesque gorges and mountains in the Pilbara, but all infrastructure was demolished in 2023. (Supplied)

"It is critical that anyone in the area complies with warning signs and road bunding that is in place for their own health and safety," a spokesperson said.

But the curiosity remains, with videos such as Ms Fontinis's attracting a considerable online audience.

"I thought it would be our version of Chernobyl, and it is in a way," she said in one video.

"[That] you'd still have buildings and play equipment, I don't know that's how I envisaged it — they've just taken everything and what's left is a few roads that nature is taking back."

'A calculated risk'

Ms Fotinis said she took precautions for her own and her daughter's safety.

"I made sure I never got out of the car," she said.

"I also made sure that my air conditioning was on recirculate, windows were up … we never touched the ground there, anything like that.

Ronelle and her daughter were able to drive around barriers to the town site, which is not gated or fenced off. (Supplied: Facebook)

"I don't believe we were any more exposed driving through there than we were in Karijini National Park when you could flick it [asbestos] off the wall."

After posting videos of her visit, Ms Fotinis said some of the feedback she had received was positive, with many recalling fond memories of their time living there or visiting.

Others called her out on her actions.

Exposed asbestos fibres can be seen at Dales Gorge in Karijini National Park. (ABC News: Michelle Stanley)

"I completely understand where they are coming from," she said.

"However, I did take a calculated risk in that sense and made sure we were as safe as.

" In hindsight, I would have definitely never taken my daughter there. "

Ms Fotinis said the blocked-off entry was very easy to bypass, with another car also having a look around while she was there.

"If [WA authorities] were dead-set serious and it was as toxic as what they were saying, it would be cleaned up for one and closed off properly for two," she said.

"I don't regret going, but at the same time, I'm not going to go back."

Towering asbestos tailings remain at the former Wittenoom mine to this day. (Supplied)

Policing a contaminated site

Due to contamination, the area is not routinely checked by WA Police or the local shire, with emergency services and police only responding to life-threatening situations.

WA Police said it was aware of the social media post and held concerns that online promotions of Wittenoom would encourage people to visit.

A spokesperson said Wittenoom was not a tourism destination.

"Doing so exposes individuals to serious health risks associated with the well-documented asbestos contamination," they said.

"The contamination at Wittenoom is permanent, and the risk to health is significant."

title: Randa Abdel-Fattah to appear at Adelaide literary event in March
text:
Palestinian Australian author Randa Abdel-Fattah will appear next month at an alternative event to this year's now-cancelled Adelaide Writers' Week, after she was uninvited from the original literary festival.

The organisers of Constellations: Not Writers' Week said Abdel-Fattah would appear in conversation with former Writers' Week director Louise Adler, who resigned last month amid furore regarding the Adelaide Festival board's decision to cancel Abdel-Fattah's scheduled appearance.

The "in conversation" event between Abdel-Fattah and Adler will be presented by the Australian Friends of Palestine Association at the Adelaide Town Hall on March 1.

Constellations: Not Writers' Week has been organised by a group of local booksellers, publishers and authors in lieu of the annual Writers' Week.

The Adelaide Festival board last month decided to rescind an invitation for Abdel-Fattah to speak at Adelaide Writers' Week because of comments she had made about Israel and Zionism.

Adelaide Writers' Week was scrapped this year amid controversy over the cancellation of Randa Abdel-Fattah. (ABC News)

Her cancellation came after SA Premier Peter Malinauskas wrote to the board strongly urging against the inclusion of Abdel-Fattah on the program of Writers' Week, saying it was "not in the public interest".

The announcement of her non-attendance prompted a mass boycott by more than 100 other authors, which in turn triggered the cancellation of the event for 2026.

Amid the controversy, the Adelaide Festival board stepped down, and a new board was swiftly appointed.

The new board later apologised to Abdel-Fattah, saying she would be invited to speak at Writers' Week upon its return in 2027.

Abdel-Fattah and Adler's appearance was one of several items on the Constellations program announced today.

Abdel-Fattah will also be appearing at a session entitled Rivers of Reason: Blak & Arab Writers in Conversation on March 2, alongside authors including Yankunytjatjara poet Ali Cobby Eckermann, novelist Melissa Lucashenko and academic Chelsea Watego, organisers said.

Adelaide-based Nobel Prize winner J. M. Coetzee is scheduled to appear at a mini-poetry festival curated by poet and former host of the ABC's Poetica program Mike Ladd.

Organisers said the Constellations line-up showcased First Nations authors, as well as interstate and international writers.

Economist and former Greek finance minister Yanis Varoufakis, who had been scheduled to talk at Writers' Week, will take part in a panel discussion at the Adelaide Town Hall alongside guests including Bob Brown.

title: This is about the best version of Pirates of Penzance you could see
text:
Advertisement

Key points OPERA: Victorian Opera puts on a joyous staging of The Pirates of Penzance

MUSIC: Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds perform at Alexandra Gardens

DANCE: Garabari at Midsumma is enjoyable – and participating is non-negotiable

JAZZ: The Necks deliver a five-star performance at Melbourne Recital Centre

THEATRE: The Placeholder at fortyfivedownstairs wades into thorny territory

OPERA

The Pirates of Penzance ★★★★

Victorian Opera, Palais Theatre, until February 6 If The Pirates of Penzance proves one point, it’s that silliness is timeless. Raucously popular for almost 150 years, a good Pirates is still a guaranteed money-spinner. This staging, originally by Opera Australia, has been met with laughter and acclaim wherever she sails. Victorian Opera is now at the helm, but audience reaction will be no different. Ben Mingay as The Pirate King. Jeff Busby With comedic plots of clever rhymes sung at rapid-fire pace to catchy melodies, Gilbert & Sullivan is a style unto itself. Pirates is the most joyous piece in the G&S canon, with innumerable proliferations across popular culture, including perhaps the most parodied song in the English language, I Am the Very Model of a Modern Major-General. VO artistic director Stuart Maunder has fashioned this production with a lifetime’s worth of devoted insight. There’s thought behind the tiniest details; he has squeezed as much funny out as is possible.

Advertisement

Ben Mingay’s much-lauded Pirate King is charismatic and wonderfully riotous, always scene-stealing. He gels naturally with Nicholas Jones, a VCA graduate turned Paris Opera principal artist, as Frederic. Jones deploys his full bag of tricks for this role: effortless operatic tenor, impeccable comedic timing, notably un-wussy sword fighting, even some ballet. Opposite him are emerging and seasoned opera darlings (respectively) Nina Korbe and Antoinette Halloran. Korbe’s coloratura hits every mark perfectly, and while Halloran’s cockney Ruth might conjure up her recent turn as Mrs Lovett, she’s reliably excellent, as is tenor Douglas Kelly as the pirate Samuel. This is just about the best version of Pirates of Penzance you can see. Jeff Busby Stage stalwart Richard Piper (Major-General Stanley) appears more at home with comedy than music. He somehow, on opening night, managed to get ahead of the orchestra during his famous number, though he still landed the laughs. Conductor James Pratt does an otherwise superb job of keeping everyone and everything together, bringing requisite buoyancy to Orchestra Victoria’s playing of the score. One omission sorely missed is surtitles. Though sung in English, diction in the chorus numbers tended towards unintelligibility. Any real pitfalls are those present in the work itself (and some are very dated). With that in mind, is this production just about the best version of Pirates that you could see? Aye aye!

Reviewed by Bridget Davies

Advertisement

MUSIC

Nick Cave and the Bad Seeds ★★★★★

Alexandra Gardens, January 30 Across his decades-long career, Nick Cave’s work has always courted darkness: his lyrics reverberate with images of biblical violence, with the ache of loneliness and grief, with the kind of love that goes hand in hand with death. Yet equally, he is attuned to beauty and salvation; to the distant, longed-for possibility of redemption. It is in the tension between these two impulses, never quite reconciled, that the strength of his artistry lies. Nick Cave and The Bad Seeds at Alexandra Gardens on Friday. Richard Clifford This artistry was on full display at Melbourne’s Alexandra Gardens, where an electrifying 2½-hour set somehow didn’t seem long enough. It’s been nine years since Cave last toured with the full complement of the Bad Seeds, and the band seems determined to make up for lost time. Every person on stage comes to the performance with absolute conviction: from Warren Ellis working his unruly magic with the violin, to the gorgeous textures of the gospel-inflected backing choir, and the magnetic, visceral energy of Cave himself.

Advertisement

“It seems like we’ve been on a great odyssey across this country to get to Melbourne,” he says, to roars of approval. This is a show for the home crowd. The set deftly balances work from the band’s 2024 album, Wild God, with cherry-picked tracks from its extensive back catalogue. An early highlight is a searching performance of O Children from the 2004 album, Abattoir Blues/The Lyre of Orpheus, while Cave’s darker impulses are on full display in the seductively menacing groove of Red Right Hand and the apocalyptic bombast of The Mercy Seat. Nick Cave’s artistry was on full display at Melbourne’s Alexandra Gardens, where an electrifying 2½-hour set somehow doesn’t seem long enough Richard Clifford While the show contains its moments of pain, rage and despair, these days, joy is perhaps Cave’s primary register. It’s there in the naive lyrics of Frogs, in his open-hearted tribute to former bandmate and collaborator Anita Lane in O Wow O Wow (How Wonderful She Is), and most defiantly in Joy, in which Cave conjures up a ghostly child visitor with a message of hope amid the tragedy of the everyday: “We’ve all had too much sorrow, now is the time for joy.” A generous, six-song encore showcases some of the band’s best work: from an elemental rendition of The Weeping Song to a sensitive cover of Young Charlatans’ Shiver (perhaps the world’s most accomplished love song ever to have been written by a 16-year-old). A luminous performance of Into My Arms brings the evening to a close: tender, plainspoken, the darkness tempered always by light.

Reviewed by Nadia Bailey

Advertisement

DANCE

MIDSUMMA | Garabari ★★★

Meat Market, North Melbourne, until January 31 Garabari is billed as a participatory event, so there’s no excuse for not playing along. Forewarned is fair warning: you’ve bought a ticket, so you’ve got to help out. It’s not going to work if you don’t bring your dancing shoes. Garabari at Midsumma Festival fits the community mood and travels well. Courtesy of Sydney Festival Yes, at first, it’s awkward. People meander through the large, dark space, drifting aimlessly and smiling apologetically. The soundscape is a disconcerting mix of creakings and scrapings. We’re warming up to the room and to each other. Of course, it’s all part of a larger narrative. We’re already inside a re-visioning of the story of the Murrumbidgee River’s creation. This first part is a time of drought, we’re told, a time of dust and heat and general suffering.

Advertisement

The performers circulate through the crowd and little dances begin to appear: fragmentary routines for two or three or four. Crowds gather and disperse. It’s as if something is bubbling away, building up. Eventually, there’s a short but effective narrative dance showing the liberation of the waters by the youngest and bravest of the goanna women. Huge shadows loom against a curtain as the earth cracks open and land is quenched. After that, the party begins in earnest. Everyone has to dance. The performers keep it moving, calling people in, co-ordinating mass choreography, whooping and hollering and carrying on. It’s diverting – even if it feels a little forced. It almost recalls the compulsory jollity of cruise ship entertainment or theatre for children, with the performers policing participation, albeit with endless grinning and an ultimately tolerant attitude to refusal. As a celebration of the stories and rituals from the Wiradjuri community around Wagga Wagga and the Riverina, where the show was developed, Garabari is enjoyable, for all its goofiness and happy-clappy enthusiasm. It’s a fun homage to the institution of corroboree. Whether it becomes anything like a true rite of passage, leaving participants altered, is another question. That’s a tall order for such a brief performance – little over an hour. But at Midsumma Festival, it fits the community mood and travels well.

Reviewed by Andrew Fuhrmann

Advertisement

JAZZ

The Necks ★★★★★

Melbourne Recital Centre, January 29 At first glance, the three members of The Necks are mere musicians. But Chris Abrahams, Lloyd Swanton and Tony Buck are also magicians. How else to explain the way they pull invisible threads of sound from the ether and fashion them – instinctively, intuitively and moment-by-moment – into perfectly formed musical tales? The Necks - Lloyd Swanton, Tony Buck and Chris Abrahams. Camille Walsh Photography Now in their 39th year together, the trio has developed the kind of creative communion that makes each fully improvised journey feel both thrillingly unpredictable and somehow inevitable. Thursday night marked the start of the band’s annual Australian tour, and an air of hushed anticipation greeted the trio’s arrival on stage. Sparsely lit and heads bowed, they waited in silence. When Swanton began plucking his bass – slowly, deliberately – it felt more like a prayer than a series of notes. Buck’s touch on cymbals was equally spare and reverential, as was Abrahams’ glistening piano.

Advertisement

Infinitesimal variations in tone and texture were explored, drawing us deep into this meditative realm as the mood gradually darkened. Related Article Melbourne live reviews Even this pop star thinks having her gig at the tennis is a bit weird Swanton’s bass morphed into an insistent buzz, its vibrations merging with Abrahams’ open-pedal piano clusters and Buck’s briskly whisked cymbals. Tranquility gave way to tension, the blood-red stage lights echoing the sense of high drama that was as menacing as it was enthralling. The second set opened in a pool of limpid beauty: exquisitely lyrical piano motifs, reverberant bass and lightly padding toms. Serene, drifting, lovely. Again, the music beckoned and disarmed us, luring us in as the restful sway turned into a more full-bodied swell and then a churning sea. This time, the roiling waves seemed majestic rather than forbidding. Perhaps by now we’d surrendered – no longer caught in the current but letting ourselves be swept along by it, just as the musicians were. Buck’s torso rocked back and forth, embodying the restless energy that coursed through the music. Agitation and abstraction; hallucinatory spirals of sound; and then, as if by magic, the waves subsided and we found ourselves gently carried back to shore.

Reviewed by Jessica Nicholas

Advertisement

THEATRE

The Placeholder ★★★

fortyfivedownstairs, until February 8 The shared experience of grief has culminated in many an incisive theatre piece centred on chosen families navigating existential questions of loss, friendship and mortality – Domenica Feraud’s off-Broadway play Someone Spectacular and, closer to home, Ash Flanders’ Malthouse production This Is Living among them. The kitchen of matriarch Pat (Meredith Rogers, centre) becomes the focal point of The Placeholder. Darren Gill Ben MacEllen’s The Placeholder is the latest play to wade into thorny territory. We’re plunged headfirst into 2017, notably the year queer communities were subjected to a postal survey on marriage equality. It’s a devastating time, illustrated by clips of real-life interviews and news segments showcasing the bigotry that was allowed to flourish. United by virtue of Barb’s Bosom Buddies – a fundraising collective dedicated to honouring the memory of namesake Barb, who died of breast cancer – five disparate people in the fictional rural town of South Bend find themselves meeting monthly to brainstorm badges, banners, cookies and muffins.

Advertisement

Related Article Performing arts What is it about this show that can prompt a lifetime of obsession? Matriarch Pat (Meredith Rogers) is a soft-spoken retiree whose kitchen becomes the focal point of the play, brilliantly materialised by Bethany J. Fellows’ set design. Helen (Michelle Perera) is a widow with a heart of gold and a penchant for baking. A proud lesbian, Keira (Rebecca Bower) self-medicates with alcohol to withstand living in a cloistered town. Barb’s niece Jo (Brigid Gallacher) is the conservative black sheep of the group. And sporty Nic (Oliver Ayres) used to go by Nicole, until they announce they’re transitioning into a man. The reprisal is swift. The elder members of the group, Pat and Helen, paradoxically take it in their stride, but Keira is incensed by the perceived loss of a lesbian peer, and Jo insists it’s all just a phase. The remainder of the play details the fallout of Nic continuously insisting on his personhood against bad-faith arguments and a gulf of miscomprehensions. As the kindest, most level-headed character, Helen is who most audiences will project themselves onto. But Perera, so brilliant in This Is Living, is also the strongest of the ensemble. Her comedic timing is impeccable as she expertly oscillates between empathetic displays of allyship and perfectly executed moments of humour that imbue the play with levity at key junctures. Pat (Meredith Rogers) and Nic (Oliver Ayres) in The Placeholder. Darren Gill

Advertisement

Functioning like a time capsule by virtue of being set nearly a decade in the past, The Placeholder provides a stage for various expressions of acceptance and opposition as the group muddles through supporting Nic. A cookie-cutter bigot, Jo’s views cover well-trodden, odious ground. But it’s Keira’s see-sawing between solidarity and gender essentialism and a self-victimisation that’s impervious to the marginalisation of others that’s harder to stomach – and altogether more interesting. MacEllen presents thought-provoking contrasts between desired gender-affirming care and unwanted life-saving surgery, gender and sexuality, mental deterioration and newly prized lucidity. But at close to three hours, The Placeholder is simply too long. MacEllen’s script retreads familiar ground in the play’s second act, which drags lugubriously to its emotional climax(es). Related Article Exclusive

Arts From a New York bathroom to regional Victoria: An exhibition of art’s heavy hitters is on its way The tenuous connecting thread of a makeshift charity doesn’t explain why these characters are so invested in one another, and why they tolerate unconscionable behaviour – particularly from Jo. As a result, the emotional payoffs are muted, hampered further by unnatural, dialogue-heavy exposition and uneven acting during key dramatic reveals. Much is left unresolved by close. Keira’s alcohol addiction continues to be the butt of jokes, Pat’s clear descent into dementia is unremarked upon. String-heavy interludes between scenes are peppered with a greatest hits compilation of what happened in the intervening years – good, bad, ridiculous. But the cacophony, so effective initially in illustrating the overwhelm of the marriage equality vote, overpowers the play by the end.
